posts.cooked:
I reread the big brother blog post and there is a statement: “the only information we can produce in response to a request like this is the date and time a user registered with Signal and the last date of a user’s connectivity to the Signal service.”

  1. The first part date and time of user registered, why is there a need to store this info and why is there a need to store time and not only date?

  2. The second part last date of user’s connectivity. What actually is this connectivity? Last call made or last text send or is there way more? Like is Signal-app time to time “calling” home, you know to tell: "I am still installed and alive."

  3. What about read receipt, typing indicators, sealed senders etc? How does all this works from perspective of meta data and connectivity? Is there some meta-data saved on server?

  4. What about rate limits? Serious system has to have some system implemented to prevent DoS attack and you need to track some metadata to be successful (on disk or at least on memory). What info is tracked and is it stored on disks?

  5. I remember (but can’t find know) the answer on this forum from OWS when one user has written that he/she assumes that whole county-X (my memory is not sharp to remember the country, maybe China) does not work and the response was, that they see connections from country-X, so whole country is not shutdown. I assume they need to have some IP tracking implemented. I am not saying they are storing this info, but at least they must be analyzing. I understand in order to understand if Signal service is running fine in the world, is there some country making censoring etc it is required to have some monitor system. There also is required some information about size of the project, so that hardware capacities may be planned. If traffic increases, if number of messages increases etc more hardware is required.

  6. There must be plenty of Signal servers all over the world. How is metadata synchronized between servers? This is probably not in Signal Server code or is it?

We actually can’t know what code is really running on the severs like official Signal Server code, but lets assume they really run Signal Server code, what I am interested what info is permanently stored (like on disks - date & time of registration, date of last connectivity, something else?) and what is at least temporally stored in RAM to make analysis: is there an abusive user sending tons of traffic, is there some country traffic does not comes from (censorship), etc.

posts.cooked:
I have read all 5 legal documents so I can help respond to some parts of this post, you can find the links to those documents at the bottom of the big brother post. Or here here here here and here
Signal was forced to give quote: ‘any and all subscriber account information’
What does this mean? This means Signal had to give everything they know about two accounts, and if they did not Signal could have been charged with obstruction of Justice or not co- operating with law enforcement and fined a lot of money, or Moxie and his team going to jail. Remember that the FBI are not ordinary police, they are investigative detectives and the best in the world, some of them are computer experts. So it is difficult to lie to them. One of the accounts was not a Signal user, so Signal could not give anything, the other was a Signal user, so the only thing Signal could give was about: The ‘last connection date’, and ‘account created’ period.

link_counts.title: Call for ideas: how to fix "dead accounts syndrome"

posts.cooked:
Junkii:

the only thing Signal could give was about: The ‘last connection date’, and ‘account created’ period.

@Junkii, like I have said I have reread the blog post and I don’t have trouble of understanding why OWS provided info to FBI. I am fine with this, we should respect the law.

I am more interested in exact technical details. What is connection from last connection date? Is it last message send, last phone call made or is there something else that “connection” is. Like when read receipt is send is this also counted as connection? Does phone make some connection to the server despite user not executing text message or phone call? I understand that last connection is kept as info, to know which user is still alive, but what is the purpose of keeping registration date and specially registration time?

shellSignal:

The first part date and time of user registered, why is there a need to store this info and why is there a need to store time and not only date ?

They could just store the year. A proposed this year’s ago. At the moment the store day,
month and year.

@nuttso, according to the blog post they store date (year, month, day) and time (probably hour, minute and second) or registration. I would like to understand why do they need so detailed info? Most probably this info is not required for day-to-day Signal operation, so I assume the info is kept for some statistical analysis, like grow of Signal users or something.

But from registration date and time there is possible to get some statistical correlation info. Like I register and few seconds after some of my friend register. Now somebody could make some assumption. Like I and my friend registered e.g 2015-05-04 at 10:15:17, so we are hiding something for 4 years.

Even from last connection (what ever this really is) can be made some correlations. For example the last connection between me and my friend is two days ago and non of us has performed any other Signal communication. From this two dates alone can be speculated that we have communicated two days ago. Yes, little speculation, but if I or my friend is the only Signal contact on a confiscate phone, this is near 100% accurate info.

Every single little harmless meta data that is collected and not really needed for day-to-day operation, is a danger it can get abused. Understanding what kind of meta data are collected and for what purpose may become vital in some cases. Reducing the collection to bare minimum is vital for users privacy.

I think they store everything as a unix time stamp. The two dates you cite above

shellSignal:

“the only information we can produce in response to a request like this is the date and time a user registered with Signal and the last date of a user’s connectivity to the Signal service.”

Are most likely required for the following reasons

  1. Check to see if a user is registered with the server
  2. If elapsed time between registration and last check in then the server will probably remove the user
  3. The time of last connection is required to manage the message queue for offline devices. Again there is most likely a limit before data is discarded and eventually not sent in the first place
  4. Time data is also used for user metrics

I’m not sure if it’s possible to remove the need for even this data, but I guess if it’s possible to not record anything then that should be the goal (but it might not be feasible).

My question is, is it possible to reduce this logging to month/year? So the day don't get logged. EDIT: Or even better what @bowensong recommends. `current_year - last_login_year > 1 `

posts.cooked:
Like shellsignal I am curious to learn the exact meaning of ‘connectivity’ because I don’t know if that means, last time Bob sent&received a UI-visible message-bubble, last time Bob sent&received a not-as-visible read-receipt or sync-message or whatnot, or something else. If Bob just opens signalapp without any messages getting moved above, did he ‘connect’ to signal-server nodes somehow? What if he sends an SMS via the SMS-integration, does that count as him connecting?

To me there is not much point in trying to further whittle down these two values. Some point, yes, just not much point: it is a good idea, but not crucial, in other words. Like was mentioned upthread, there is some circumstantial value to a precision timestamp. I suspect the reason that signalapp tries to keep the exact timestamp of registration, is related to HTTP 413 errors when registration-attempts are rate-limited. However, once a person has successfully registered, methinks there is gradually less reason to retain the initial precision. Maybe after a person has been registered at least a week or two, their registered-on-timestamp can be rounded to the nearest day/date value, and when registered for over a month, rounded again to the nearest month?

By contrast, we need at least day/date precision for the getLastSeen value, because it is used for the registration-pin-lock feature (which can hold a phone-num to a particular owner based on their memorized pin-lock for up to 7 days of inactivity). Repository search results · GitHub is the code where the LastSeen value is updated, but I’m not sure when (in terms of what client-side UI/UX activity) those funcalls actually would happen.

shellSignal:

a request like this

To me, that emphasized bit is the most worrisome part of the quote. The request asked OWS to provide information two registered people. The lawyers asked about +1-111-111-1111 and about +2-222-222-2222 … not the real nums btw ;-)

In return, they got the following: +1-111-111-1111 is “not” a registered phone-num, which to me implies, probably was registered at one point (since the lawyers believed that num was used to send&receive signalapp message at some point in the past), but later unregistered and was deleted server-side, prior to the subpoena arriving. And then, for +2-222-222-2222, which was still registered and thus not deleted server-side, the info was the last day/date of connectivity, and the date&timestamp when the enduser registered. Changes suggested above might lessen the precision of one of those values, but both values are needed server-side for some useful purposes.

shellSignal:

I assume they need to have some IP tracking implemented. I am not saying they are storing this info

The core of the problem is that the internet requires IP addresses, basically, and network-debugging requires logfiles. Signal-server nodes are supposed to be setup not to store IP addresses, nor other low-level metadata either, but could be altered by Aussies or the UK to do so, theoretically at least.

shellSignal:

How is metadata synchronized between servers?

The backend database-dependency is PostgreSQL and it supports replication, so my guess (but with no inside info) is that signal-server nodes are configured to connect to a replicated postgres backend-cluster.

shellSignal:

We actually can’t know what code is really running on the severs

This is changing, slowly and gradually: one of the main points of server-side SGX enclaves for the ContactDiscovery portion of the codebase, is so that the client-side signal4android and signal4ios apps can cryptographically verify that the server-side code is running the hashed value they expect for that codebase, prior to uploading hashes of their social-graph phone-nums. I hope that this expands as time goes on, to get runtime validation of what code the server is running for more and more of the server-side codebase.

shellSignal:

what I am interested what info is permanently stored (like on disks - date & time of registration, date of last connectivity, something else?)

Permanent on-disk storage of metadata is purposely very limited, by design: there is a list of all phone-nums that have registered with signal-server. For each phone-num, the date&time they registered, and the day/date they last contacted signal-server (might be per-linked-device rather than per phone-num?). Every linked device has a server-side queue of end2end-encrypted messages awaiting delivery, usually empty unless the device in question is powered down or otherwise offline; thanks to sealed sender, these are quite opaque nowadays. Most phone-nums have a signal-profile, and many have a signal-profile-avatar-pic, which are stored in S3 buckets, with unique identifiers as Amazon-filenames, but always end2end encrypted in terms of their contents.

shellSignal:

and what is at least temporally stored in RAM

In-RAM storage is a lot more problematic, which is why it is important that signal-servers be hardened against temporary or permanent pwn’age by an adversary… a very powerful adversary with broad visibility of big chunks of the internet overall (Amazon/Google/NSA and a few others like them) can also do traffic analysis even without server-pwn’ing methinks, but this is a speculative area where it is hard to come to firm conclusions.

By contrast, even temporary signal-server pwn’age is very bad: for rate-limiting reasons, there are pairwise phone-nums in RAM, for example. And most people that accept the defaults, upload brute-force-crackable hashes of the phone-nums of all the people they have in their addressbook every N hours (maybe N=6 if memory serves).

Signal-server is still best-in-class: even a temporary pwn’age of whatsapp servers would give the adversary 100% of your groupchats and tons of other metadata (and to the extent the adversary in question being able to pwn whatsapp servers also means they can pwn facebook servers… VAST troves of data and metadata about you and everybody you have ever known would be at their fingertips). Quite frankly, even though I’ve never had a whatsapp install nor a facebook page, I’m confident that an adversary would learn a lot more about me by breaching the facebook-and-whatsapp servers than they would learn by breaching the signal-servers :-) But that is no excuse for signal-server getting complacent, there are still a lot of improvements which could be made, along the same line of thinking as sealed sender and CDS enclaves, that will significantly improve metadata-resistance (and eventually even traffic-analysis-resistance)

posts.cooked:
5_c_d:

If Bob just opens signalapp without any messages getting moved above, did he ‘connect’ to signal-server nodes somehow?

Yes, when you open it, Signal connects to the service to check for new messages.

haffenloher:

Yes, when you open it, Signal connects to the service to check for new messages.

I can back this up with my personal experience. I was unaware to disable battery optimization, so I did not recieve Signal messages for a long time. As soon as I opened and ran the app all my messages that were qued up on the server started coming in. So simply just opening the app connects the app to the servers to start recieving messages.

haffenloher:

when you open it, Signal connects to the service to check for new messages.

What about if you do not open the Signal for some time. Signal is run in background. Does it checks time to time the servers or does it strictly relays on GCM and waits GCM notifies the Signal background client service on new message arrival?

The bottom line is I would like to know what does connectivity means. I have few Signal users that I do not contact or get contacted for very long period like few mounts or more. I know they still have Signal app installed. If Signal app’s background service time to time connects to Signal servers, then they can have Signal installed for years (assuming they install app updates) and then when I message them, message is going to go through. But if they have Signal app installed and just forgot about it (not using it) and there is no contact Signal home, then after few months I will not be able to contact them using Signal.

The court documents don’t tell us anything, because they only decribe the case of the specific user who may or may have not used all of Signal’s features.

Thinking about it, one can easily come up with other data that is probably stored. I think it looks more or less like this:

  • date of registration
  • phone number
  • IDs of group chats the user is a member of
  • Number of linked devices
  • Pre-generated long-term / short-term keys by Signal protocol
  • Blocked users
  • link to profile pic stored in the cloud
  • messages queued for delivery to linked device x / y / z
  • IP address (to prevent DDoS)
  • registration lock set / not set
  • allow Sealed Sender from everyone (or not)
  • Push tokens for Apple / Google

anon57865533:
  • IDs of group chats the user is a member of
  • Blocked users

This is stored purely on the clients (also the reason for making group administration features pretty difficult).

anon57865533:
  • link to profile pic stored in the cloud

To keep in mind, this information is stored encrypted.

anon57865533:

IP address (to prevent DDoS)

I’m very sure this is true. Would like to know how they did make it not to handle this data over to police in this particular case. The only option i can think of, is that they don’t attach it to your signal account. They don’t have to know the account to prevent ddos from an IP.

nuttso:

The only option i can think of, is that they don’t attach it to your signal account.

FBI requested the data from phone number. Because OWS do not tracks users by IP, they can’t give this data to them.

What I am sceptical is, what if law enforcement request that OWS starts to collect IP addresses for particular user. We would not know that, because server code would be changed without users to notice. In this way geolocation by network would be possible. Relatively know where individual is by approximate location at least.

The other thing I am sceptical is, OWS need to get explicit approval to publish subpoena data. We just don’t know how many if any new subpoena was issued and process is still not in the phase that can be revealed to the public or may never be.

shellSignal:

What I am sceptical is, what if law enforcement request that OWS starts to collect IP addresses for particular user.

I’m not a lawyer, but I’m pretty sure that law enforcement in the US can only compel you to hand over certain types of data that you already have, not to start collecting new data or to write and deploy code.

@haffenloher, I am also not a lawyer, I was thinking Australian have issued some law that forces developers to cooperate.

For US, if such a subpoena is issued, I wonder if OWS must apply it immediately or can they complain on court and if they lose then implement the spying feature.

Correct, the new Aussie law is something that could be used to compel deployment (and OWS would not even write the code necessarily… they would just be forced to hand over the ssh login to the signal-server-nodes). Similar laws existed in the UK already, long before the Aussie thing, is my understanding. Shockingly: also not a lawyer, sorry-not-sorry :-) So take with a grain of salt.

There is such a thing as a National Security Letter, in the USA, but for a typical policing action taken by law enforcement (up to and including federal FBI/DEA/BATFE/similar kinds of law enforcement) I believe that haffenloher is correct.

nuttso:

they don’t attach it [IP addr] to your signal account [phone-num aka signal-identifier]

This is true, and moreover, at least some of the DDoS and rate-limiting are done on a phone-number basis (i.e. not with IP at all), see the Signal's stubborn insistence upon using Google Cloud Messaging (which is mostly ... | Hacker News thread about pairwise-phone-nums-in-ram mentioned earlier.

But what threat-model are we talking about here?

Fundamentally, the worry here is that either a governmental actor, or worse a skilled cracker-group, might be able to rootkit one of the signal-server nodes and record all the IP info and other network-level stuff, as well as all the phone-nums and protocol-level metadata, and then perform some traffic-analysis and timing-analysis to figure out who all the groupchat members are (and the geolocation of those not using Tor+VPN+etc). Server-side attackers with enough time and access, can partly convert a signal-server into something more like a whatsapp server.

Unless they are VERY sophisticated adversaries, they will not be able to breach the SGX enclaves where the social-graph addressbook-uploads are temporarily in RAM. Similarly, they will not be able to breach the end2end crypto, which protects signal-nicknames and signal-avatar-pics and the like. But there is a lot of metadata, and if they are sophisticated enough to get it from RAM prior to OWS deleting it, they are probably sophisticated enough to perform some endpoint attacks, as well.

Which is why, although I think this is a good discussion-topic, to me it is mostly academic. Yes, given an extremely powerful adversary, who is slick enough and savvy enough to get past all Moxie’s defenses, hoodwink Brian Acton, and trick Greyson … well, yeah, they could install a rootkit onto the signal-server nodes, and then with a lot of sophisticated traffic analysis and timing analysis, figure out enough to pressure the weakest link of a 99-member groupchat. But if they ARE that powerful and sophisticated and savvy… they don’t really need to perform a server-attack. Cheaper and easier for them to monitor regular internet traffic and telco traffic (facebook pages and CDR and whatnot), and then perform tailored access operations directly against the endpoint devices. Signal-server nodes are hosted by AWS nowadays… probably less expensive just to monitor all IP traffic on AWS, and then target suspicious endpoints directly, all things considered.

And “all things” includes public relations. Cracking into signal-servers is a risky op, because if you are caught, you don’t get off scott-free. OWS has been very careful to make friends in the press, and to some degree, in the political realm as well. Of the groups that are capable of attacking and compromising a signal-server node, the majority are major foreign governments and/or their pet cracker-groups: China, Israel, Russia, probably some of the EU countries, things like that. Cracking into signal-server would risk not just a diplomatic incident, but a ground war, depending on who did it and whether they had tacit approval of USA politicians or not (cf in-the-political-realm stuff above… and remember that OWS is right in Pelosi’s district so there are turf-wars within turf-wars here potentially).

And as risky as it would be for a non-USA group to crack into signal-server, and get caught… what about for a USA-based entity, especially a tech-giant or a federal government agency? Again, OWS is in Pelosi’s turf, and in the middle of Silicon Valley, too. It would be extremely risky business for any group to try cracking into signal-server, unless they could do so without being caught… or really, even suspected. If there is a breach-attempt against signal-server someday, my first suspicion is that it will be a false-flag :-) Paradoxically, locating OWS in the jurisdiction it is in, rather than Switzerland or the Seychelles or whatever, might be the best way to “hide in plain sight” …all the big players that actually have the funding and the skillset to compromise a server-node, seemingly cannot take the risk of doing so (or even appearing to do so methinks).

In other words, I think that worrying about metadata-in-RAM on signal-server is a very valid worry, and I’d like to see more work done on shifting to SGX enclaves what can be shifted… but I think the right design-tradeoffs are being made, to keep the servers secure enough. (E.g. sealed sender and SGX as defenses against server-seizure risks.) Such that, specifically, the “real” worry / the most pertinent worry / the worry that will actually bite you, is very definitely still endpoint-opsec. By design, since endusers that are especially security-conscious can do something about their endpoint-opsec! :-)

link_counts.title: Signal's stubborn insistence upon using Google Cloud Messaging (which is mostly ... | Hacker News

posts.cooked:
anon57865533:
  • date of registration
  • phone number

Those above are kept on-disk, along with rounded-to-the-nearest-day/day LastSeen.

anon57865533:
  • Number of linked devices
  • messages queued for delivery to linked device x / y / z
  • Pre-generated long-term / short-term keys by Signal protocol
  • registration lock set / not set

I believe all those are implicitly available on signal-server, yes… though to be clear, the prekeys are not the same as the device-level private-keys which protect crypto, the short-term-prekeys and the long-term prekey even, are just used to communicate with an enduser’s signal-identifier-phone-num, i.e. they are public-keys-not-private-ones.

the rest is in RAM, or when possible, purely client-side
anon57865533:
  • IP address (to prevent DDoS)

This is stored in RAM, but my understanding is that it gets flushed as soon as the socket is closed. I’m not sure there is much IP-level anti-DDoS, nor rate-limiting. An area I would like to know more about, though, since as ShellSignal mentions, this is geolocation-data. How is it kept separated / unlinked from the phone-num, is my other main question (typically the delivery-queue would have to be associated with the signal-identifier, would it not?)

anon57865533:
  • IDs of group chats the user is a member of
  • Blocked users
  • allow Sealed Sender from everyone (or not)
  • link to profile pic stored in the cloud
  • Push tokens for Apple / Google

My understanding is that these are all client-side, in some way. I think the groupchat uuid is never the “recipient” of a message… messages are sent to individual members, not to the group. So there is a heat-bloom when a 99-member groupchat message goes out: suddenly 99 server-side queues get a new envelope. But I think the uuid of the groupchat itself (which is necessary to attempt to join the group) is not kept server-side.

Blocked users are handled client-side, is my understanding, 100%. Messages from Bob to Alice are always delivered, and if Bob is blocked, they are silently dropped. This is inefficient in bandwidth (Bob could annoy Alice by trying to eat up her dataplan allotment), but is the correct decision for privacy methinks.

I hypothesize – but do not know for sure – that sealed sender is handled on the client-side, like blocking. If Alice sends a sealed-sender message to Bob, and Bob’s device refused to accept it because it is configured only to allow sealed-sender from certain folks (default setting), there is some retry logic, and Alice’s device auto-re-sends the message.

Profile-avatar-picture-imagefiles are stored in an S3 bucket separate from attachments… and I believe they are not touched by signal-server, client-apps that are given the relevant Amazon S3 uuid-filename, know to retrieve it, and do so directly. The profile-content itself is end2end encrypted. Traffic analysis at the network level (of all AWS) by Amazon or Google or the NSA or a similarly all-powerful adversary, could link one’s IP to which profile-pics one has contact with, but the most likely way to de-anonymize a profile-pic and get it associated with a phone-num, is via endpoint-device-seizure and subsequent forensics, methinks.

I have tried and failed to understand the exact way that GCM is utilized within signalapp. Every endpoint-device has a device-id of some kind, that is known to the google servers which handle push-notifications. Signalapp has an app-id utilized during GCM wake-up-and-check-your-messages notifications. There is no payload besides a zero-byte one, the implicit wake-up, since January 2015 revamp of the code and the re-brand as Signal (whereas in the TextSecure prototype of push-messaging there was message-payload.)

But usually, my reading of the GCM docs suggests, the signal-server would need to keep track of a unique ID for every client-device, if they wanted to track that info… and I’m not sure they do keep track thataway, since obviously they do not want that info :-) But logically, there must be some way that signal-server tells google GCM backend, “hey tell device XYZ to check signalapp messages”. What is XYZ? The phone-num of the device? The device-id of the GCM-login of the device? Some third identifier which obscures both of those from signal-server?

Not sure about this one, and would love to be straightened out. Can one implicitly figure out the GCM-device-id, and/or the gmail account name&email, of a particular enduser… if given malicious control of all signal-server nodes? Or is that somehow not possible, unless the adversary is also getting cooperation from google? What about the APNS and the AppleID, is that similar at-risk and/or similarly obfuscated-from-an-adversary-not-in-cahoots-with-apple-itself?


  • need to add: isTypingIndicators
  • need to add: read-receipts

The server does not explicitly store whether these (either of them) are enabled or not, I believe (in RAM nor on-disk), but somebody with access to the RAM info of some server-nodes, would be able to figure out via timing-analysis whether they were turned on, methinks.

  • maybe need to add: TURN nodes, during call-setup (hosted by OWS?)
  • probably need to add: STUN nodes, during call-setup
  • may need to add: GoogleMap nodes, during share-location (and recipients viewing it)
  • no need to add: Giphy servers (all requests relayed via signal-server)

Not sure what the ToS for gmaps is… can signal-server shield the IP addresses of the people involved in share-a-location, or does gmaps ToS require they all query the gmap for 123 Gobbler’s Knob Road, Punxatawny PA 44444, from their own device IP addrs? Or like the giphy service, can signal-server relay requests and shield the downstream IPs.

STUNs may capture pairwise-IP-address info, unless relay-all-calls is optionally enabled, is my understanding? And I’m not sure, but I believe the STUN nodes at least (not sure about the TURN nodes as they are configured in signal-server YML and not disclosed that I am aware) are not OWS-hosted systems, but instead nodes owned by google (even during signal4ios-to-signal4ios cryptocalls). I don’t understand STUN well enough to say what metadata those systems receive though.

This is stored purely on the clients

Good for privacy, not so good for “DoS” protection of individual users, right? You could “DoS” people who blocked you by sending them 100MB files in the background and their data plan would be drained quite easily…
